This is a mount used to secure a GoPro to the bottom of the seat of a bike. A GoPro filming in this location creates great B-roll videos to supplement your biking videos. In addition to the printed bracket, I used 3x standard GoPro thumb screws and 3x hex-nuts that can be pulled from any GoPro mount.

Each bike seat and seat rails are different, so I included the Solidworks file for you to remix.

CAD: Solidworks
Slicer: Simplify3D
Printer: Wanhao i3 Plus
Material: The bracket in the picture was printed with PLA. However, for a functional print like this, ABS is usually better. I have not tested the mount extensively, but I do not see the durability of PLA being an issue.

comments.text: i havent seen any evidence that it helps increese air flow. though i did notice a diference in the sound of the fan. the only changes i am going to  make is make it a bit thicker on the mounting tabs.
comments.author: atillad

comments.text: Love the design just wish this would make my printer sound better as if it was in a car haha. Would this fit onto both fans too?
comments.author: JMRZL

comments.text:
Nice looking indeed, but is it really efficicent ?
Any measured results ?
Such trumpet have this shape in order to optimize air admission in a thermic motor where admission varies, it's not our case
We have only to look after the venturi effect to raise air speed just before impalers, but be sure the volume stays the same, only the pressure and the celerity change
The goal is to measure how much of that flow reach blower holes
I may test it out of a printer with a monitored fan if your are motived to improve your model ;)
comments.author: Ebola57

comments.text: Hi, that would be great! I don't have the means to do experimental measurements nor to run a cfd analysis, but i'm definitely open to suggestions!
comments.author: Ebola57

comments.text: I would have liked the tabs to be a bit thicker, but it was necessary to have them this size so I did not have to use longer screws. This is an excellent design that assists in guiding a larger volume of air into the fan; it sort of organizes the incoming air. I noticed my prints immediately improved especially where I had small details and overhangs.

comments.text: thank you, glad you liked it!

comments.text: Not enough CFMs to change the sound. You hear the chopping of the blades rather than the suction through carbs.

title: Hictop Iron Man LCD Cover  3DP-08 Acrylic

description.text: I printed Neildon's cover, but my board was about 1-2mm wider than his. Since it didnt worked, i modified it to fit my board (holes spacing are the same), added some supports for the LCD itself and made channels for the nuts to lock from the back. I also opened the bottom corner, because my ribbon cables were thicker and slightly wider than his. Then i edited the back cover to be cooler since im a huge Iron Man fan. The rear cover doesnt need bolts for me, they are snug and holds cover in very nicely.

Let me start out by saying that this is not an easy project you will need a basic understanding of electronics and soldering. You will also need to remove some parts from the raspberry pi and lcd driver board so they can fit in the case. This will void the warranty of the parts. I accept no responsibility for any damages you may cause during this process.

These are the parts i used for this project. You will also need some basic tools like a soldering iron, screw drivers and wire cutters.

https://www.amazon.com/Raspberry-Pi-Model-512MB-Computer/dp/B00LPESRUK/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&qid=1486470720&tag=thngvrs-20&sr=8-3&keywords=raspberry+pi+b+&linkCode=ll1

https://www.amazon.com/Raspberry-Pi-7-Touchscreen-Display/dp/B0153R2A9I/ref=as_li_ss_tl?s=pc&ie=UTF8&qid=1486470741&tag=thngvrs-20&sr=1-2&keywords=raspberry+pi+touchscreen&linkCode=ll1

The raspberry pi screen comes with a short DSI Ribbon Cable you will need a longer one about 15 cm long. I had one from an old printer i used but i'm sure you can find one online if you don't have one.

https://www.amazon.com/Straight-Solder-Type-Female-Connector/dp/B0094DXENY/ref=as_li_ss_tl?_encoding=UTF8&pd_rd_i=B0094DXENY&pd_rd_r=XA1MGF6A8W89PV8CZHSW&pd_rd_w=UWvqg&pd_rd_wg=J2SrQ&psc=1&tag=thngvrs-20&refRID=XA1MGF6A8W89PV8CZHSW&linkCode=ll1

https://www.amazon.com/Rii-Wireless-Keyboard-Touchpad-Rechargable/dp/B00WQG6A8C/ref=as_li_ss_tl?s=pc&ie=UTF8&qid=1486470927&tag=thngvrs-20&sr=1-4&keywords=rii+mini+keyboard&linkCode=ll1

https://www.amazon.com/2-54mm-40-Pin-Female-Header-Connector/dp/B00R1LLM1M/ref=as_li_ss_tl?s=aps&ie=UTF8&qid=1486483960&tag=thngvrs-20&sr=1-2-catcorr&keywords=female+header+pins+2+x+20+row&linkCode=ll1

https://www.amazon.com/Uxcell-Ribbon-Cable-Length-40-Way/dp/B01E78ZD02/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&qid=1486484998&tag=thngvrs-20&sr=8-3&keywords=40+way+ribbon+cable&linkCode=ll1

I will not go over every step of this build but i will try and give you a basic idea of how it goes together.

You will need to remove the usb port on the lcd driver and the two dual usb ports on the raspberry pi (the usb ports on the side of the case are wired straght into the board). You will also have to remove the Ethernet port.

I removed the battery from the rii mini keyboard and wired it straight to 5v and ground on the gpio. I also disassembled the receiver and soldered it to one of the spare usb ports on the raspberry pi.

The gpio is wired to a female header on the side for easy use. If you don't need access to the gpio you don't need to do this.

To assemble the laptop you will need 9 m3 x10mm bolts and 2 M3 x 25mm bolts with 4 nuts. The lid screws onto the lcd with 4 M3 x 10mm bolts and the base is screwed onto the keyboard holder with 5 M3 x 10mm bolts. To hold the hinges together i used 2 m3 x 25mm bolts with 2 nuts on the end to lock it in place.

As always if you have any questions or ideas on how to improve this project please comment or send me a message.

Use 2 base hangers + 2 side hangers to support your mirror securily. Use woodscrews #6 to hold in place. be sure to screw in hard backwall

My girlfriend asked me to install a long mirror in the closet. So I measure the frame of it with a digital caliper. Then I design 2 hangers with that specs in mind:

  • the hangers should be strongs enought to support the mirror (euh...basics!)
  • don't want the hangers to come over the frame to avoid scratching
  • the base hangers screw should be blinded
    So I design simple hangers on Inventor in minutes, export it in stl and was ready to print in less a quarter an hour. Printed well and fitted well to, once I got the right screws! ;)

Hallo Zusammen,
hier findet Ihr einen Kreisel im Bubbledesign. Ich habe Ihn entworfen weil ich die verfügbaren Kreisel nicht optimal auf den 3D-Druck angepasst waren. Ich habe Ihn in der Mitte vom Schwerpunkt geteilt, damit man keine überhänge drucken muss. Um die zwei Teile miteinander zu verbinden benutzt ihr am besten Sekundenkleber. Damit die Teile beim Kleben perfekt aufeinander sitzen, habe ich eine Klebevorrichtung entworfen die ihr auch mit drucken könnt.
Viel Spaß beim Drucken.

Hey Guys,
here´s another gyroscope. The unique on this part is, that I've design it to print without overhangs. I´ve split the gyroscope at the center of gravity. Now it´s easy to print. You can join the 2 parts with superglue. You also can find a appliance tool for the gluing process for a perfect fit.
Enjoy.

description.text: customized with 3D Slash!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2f81D9arYGY
Read the full guide on: https://learn.adafruit.com/camera-ring-led-light/overview

This 3D printed lighting rig is a great DIY build for your photo and video projects.

It uses an Adafruit Trinket and NeoPixel LEDs. It’s also portable and battery powered or you can plug it into the wall.

In a previous project, we made a ring light for DSLR camera using a 60 NeoPixel ring.

This new version uses RGBW type NeoPixels which produces much better lighting.

White light from RGB type NeoPixels produces a reddish hue on skin tones and gives an unnatural color temperature.

RGBW type of NeoPixels provide dedicated white light which produces much better color temperature.

Combining RGB colors together creates a white light but this just doesn’t look too good on camera.

Your phone snaps onto the 3D printed bumper, making a great lighting solution for your front facing camera.

description.text:
I remixed this because i could not obtain the same hardware as was used in the original. I got a bag of assorted springs from princess Auto. I had some M3x45 bolts in my spare bolt kit. and extra M3 nuts from the Printer kit. The spring was about 6mm diameter by 40mm uncompressed,

On the front piece that holds the sensor I added ( subtracted) a slot 8mm wide by 10mm deep to accommodate the compressed spring if needed. I changed the round recesses for the sensor mounting bolts to 5.55mm hex to hold a nut and then place the bolt through the front of the sensor. I replaced the stock M3x20mm bolts with nes that were 25mm long. I have to add some washers to keep the threaded portion from dragging on the other piece . M3x22mm would have been perfect

In the back plate I increased the depth of teh recess for the mount holes another 1mm. I also moved them down 5mm.

I have the original mounted with the sensor plate rotated 180 degrees from the intended orientation so I could file a slot for the spring. With the sensor mounted as high as I could place it, I have a bit less then 2mm of adjustment left. the changes i mad wil leave me with about 7mm of adjustment room at the end of the day plus if I have to swap the 30mm heat break with a 26mm one, i can still accommodate that.

Printer:

HICTOP 3dp-17

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

30
Clean up the prints to allow easy movement but not so much that it is sloppy.

This is a z axis stabilizion for the Cetus3D Printer
the z axis is just fixed one one side - it works good - but it isent very stiff.
This mod will fix the zaxis on a second spot - so it is mutch stiffer.
i used it now for 3 days and it also seams that the artifacts on the sides are getting lesser - so it has a real effect on the printquality.

under Post-Printing you find a video witch shows the instalation :)

what you need to install thes mod:

3x M4x12mm screws
3x M4 Nuts (low profile - they just 2mm thick - DIN439/ISO4035)
2x M3x25mm screws
2x M3 nuts
1x washer for m3 screws

if you cant get thes low profile m4 nuts - you can print the "high" verion of extrusion nuts - but i recomend the lower profile.

i have 2 version - i use the nurmal version (printed in PLA with 99% infill)
the second one (slim) i dident test now - it may be enough but i like to get secure and use the thicker one :)

if you try the slim version, let me know what you think :)

This is a holder for a NEMA 17 stepper motor. It should be compatible with most motors of that size, but I'm not sure.
UPDATE!!
This was designed for wall mounting the motor, for an AS220 style drawbot. Since my motor has a small shaft coming out the back, I designed some spacers to allow the mount to sit flat.

Cut all parts out of 3mm (1/8\") material. I used baltic birch. Cut one bottom piece (the one with holes in it), and two of the top pieces. Also cut one (or more, depending on rear shaft length) of spacer.dxf. Glue the two top pieces together, and check the fit of your motor. Then glue on the bottom, using the motor to check alignment. Finally, glue on the spacers as shown. Done!
The cb files are for CamBam, the CAM program for my mill.
This could also be lasercut, you would just eliminate the pocket on the bottom.

title: Glow in the Dark Camper Key Sleeve

description.text:
This is more of an idea that a usable file unless your key measures .830" X .967".
Since we bought our camper I have found it difficult to see what key to use to unlock the door. So when I had extra keys made I decided to print my own sleeve encapsulating the key out of glow in the dark PLA. I printed the lower section and programmed a pause just before the top fill and placed the key in it before restarting the print. I sprayed the key with Aquanet and left it on the bed, during lower section printing, to get hot so the PLA would adhere to it. I inadvertently set the bed to 105 degrees rather than the normal 50 degrees for PLA.... worked so good I did the same thing on the second key. When I went to the camper at night it was so much easier to find the key and it also illuminated the lock just a little bit.

description.text:
The power supplier used in the many of the 3D printers (type e.g. S-180) has very flimsy power terminal cover. The high power line terminals are just hair length away from the fingers or tools. The cover has not locking mechanism either. For the electric safety, I made the additional cover which keeps also the original cover locked.,

You might to add the heat ´shrinking tube to cover the power terminal connectors.

My old bed leveler design allowed too much movement of the bed plate, so I re-designed and simplified it to utilize the screw holes in the 200mm print bed and increased the bed stabilization, which improved print quality dramatically.
You will need 30mm or so screws, nuts, 2020 extrusion nut + a small screw to lock it down and a spring, I got my springs out of dead inkjet printers, but they are pretty easy to find.

I am going to drill a small 1/8 inch hole through the shaft so I can use a pull-cord with my wooden top spinner handle and really get this spinning!

It can be printed without support, laying on the flat side. Additionally you need 2x (40x40 mm fans) and 2x (M4x16 mm) screws.

comments.author: ErikRL

comments.text: Hey ErikRL,
comments.author: ErikRL

comments.text: Nice!
comments.author: rnakamoto

comments.text:
Hey rnakamoto,
just remove the plug from one of the new fans. Then cut the wire from the other fan a few centimeters behind the plug and connect all black wires together and all the red ones (wired parallel). Then insulate everything.
comments.author: rnakamoto

comments.text: Would that be sufficient to run two 50mm 12v radial fans?
comments.author: Phenix_Engineering

comments.text: Should work. I mounted 2x40 mm and 2x120 mm fans that way. But I never calculated it.

description.text:
This Is Extremely Simple RC Rover with only 5 3D printed parts.
No Suspension and No steering needed.
It is 4 wheel drive and Skid-steer (like tank) turn.
It is Extremely Fast and total power of 4 motors close to 1 HP.
It is designed for 4x 5010-14 360KV RC Timer motors

You need to rotate the model upside-down (180 deg.) in Cura before sending it to 3D printer. I will add support for customizer and with correctly rotated in next update.

For installation:
Make 62mm diameter hole in ceiling for this 60mm mount.
The sensor hole is 23mm diameter.

These pieces allow you to use your printer as a plotter. It consists of a bracket that fits on the Cubicon Single extruder, and a set of adaptors (printed in Ninjaflex flexible filament) that connect a pen to the bracket. I used it so the pen is 0.2 mm lower than the print head. The bracket also uses an M4 12mm screw and bolt to secure it to the print head.

I used Simplify3D to convert gray scale images to 3D litophanes first, and with the help of some post processing create g-code files that do the plotting.

Check out (this video) by Tech2C to get you started.

A couple of things to keep in mind:

  • The plotter is running without heating the extruder, so you need to unload the fillament before using it as a plotter and disable the fillament detection in the Cubicon Single configuration.

  • Because the Cubicon Single has an auto leveling feature that starts at the beginning you can not put the pen it at the start. A very slow y-axis movement at the start of the actual printing needs to be added to the gcode to allow you to put it in.

  • You need to make sure that the pen makes as little contact with the paper as possible, in order to keep it from tilting when plotting.

  • You need to attach the paper to the printer bed with clamps. Make sure these are not in the way during the callibration at the start!

  • You may need to addapt the flexible adapter to fit your own pens.

  • UPDATED: The bracket contains support material (between the ridges on the inside) that needs to be removed.

I added one .hvs file (gcode file for the Cubicon Single) to show the resulting gcode.

Disclaimer: use at your own risk. Do not try this unless you know what you are doing!
Designed in Onshape (link to design files).

Mini breadboard
9V battery
9V battery clip with 2.1mm plug
4 male to female jumper wires
Around 20 male to male jumper wires
Around 50 2M bolts 12mm length and 50 nuts
Foam or other non smooth material for the tires

The total cost of parts is around $20.

title: MP Select Mini 8mm Gantry Support and Logitech C525 Mount

description.text:
This is a multi-project remix/mashup for the MP Select Mini.

Foremost, it is a remix of svideo's X Gantry Support + Camera Mount which adds support for an 8mm rod and bearings. If that's what you're after, you can just grab "base" and "bracket" and be good to go! Note that I while I simply enlarged the rod opening on the base, I did entirely rebuild the bracket to add the following niceties:

  • Larger zip-tie holes to accomodate 5mm zip-ties (stronger grip)
  • Rounded over zip-tie holes
  • Accommodation for slightly larger screw heads

Secondly, it is a further remix of svideo's camera boom arm (itself a remix of 3dkarma's Raspberry Pi Camera Mount with Ball Joint) that makes the following changes to add length and rigidity:

  • The boom base has two zip-tie holes that align with the middle holes in the bracket to give it much greater attachment rigidity
  • The boom arm has been lengthened to a total of 110mm
  • A rigidity panel has been added to the boom arm
  • The boom base and boom ball socket now take four arms instead of two

Finally, it updates Lord_Vader's C525 Cam Holder for Printers making it compatible with the aforementioned camera mount. Note: If the ball joint prints too small, you can scale it up by 1-2% in your slicer and print again.

Parts

  • 8mm Linear Motion Rod
  • 8mm Linear Motion Bearings
  • 2 x M3 15mm screws (for rod holder base)
  • 2 x M3 hex nuts (for rod holder base)
  • 2 x M3 30mm screws (for the camera boom)
  • 2 x M3 wingnuts (for the camera boom)
  • 4 x 5mm zip ties

I use the camera mount to live-stream printing at https://www.twitch.tv/sihren

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/i6OneE076St

This is a mount for a SMA-socket for a MK808B android tv stick. The wifi is very poor on this stick and a modification to external antenna is a big improvement. The MK808 actually has two antennas but I have only modified the receiving aerial.
Print the mount and heat up the upper part with a heat gun and push the sma socket through. It will stay in place without a nut.
I added two different versions for two antennas as well in case you want both, transmitting and receiving aerial.

title: The ARegoCW Tximy3D2 3D Printer, all axis trapezoidal screw design with aluminum T 2020 profile

description.text:
This is my New designed 3D printer, the name is ARegoCW Tximy3D2 and the structure is 2020 aluminum T profile, all axis are trapezoidal screw design and I use a 2GT timing belt to synchronous multi nema axis to prevent lost steps and power the accuracy and performance. It is under development.
The V36 updated the Y axis optical end stop support and flag, the v43 upgrade X axis optical endstop and flag without screw.
The printer are working fine ;)

Materials :
1 x lead screw 580mm for X axis
2 x lead screw 500mm for Y axis
2 x lead screw 500mm for Z motors axis
1 x lead screw 540mm for Z rear axis
Total: 4 x 500mm, 1x 600mm, 1x 550mm. and 6 x lead screw nuts

12 x 500mm 20x20 aluminium T profile
2 x 500x8mm rods for X axis
4 x KP08 for 3 Z axis
2 x KFL08 for X axis
4 x 20 teeth 8mm bore 2GT pulley, one for X axis lead screw and three for Z axis lead screws
1 x 20 teeth 5mm bore 2GT pulley for X axis motor
2 x 16 teeth 5mm bore 2GT pulley for Y axis synchronise
1 x 98 2GT-6 belt
4 x 5mm to 8mm bore adapter, two for Z motors axis and two for Y axis
4 x LM8UU bearing for the X axis carriage

many M5 screws, hex nuts and T profile nuts

Hotbed installed and working fine https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KVMgn-SZig4
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y8rf-tc5H1U

Cold bed print try, and working Ok https://youtu.be/r5hEbrAJJU0
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QP25mCanAqw

V44 incorpore support and fixations for Z axis, and many parts are coming soon.

V55 the printed parts are finished.
https://youtu.be/5S0kTQgBDBw
https://youtu.be/lqJZDlGUMR8
ARegoCW Tximy3D1 printing the latest V55 update https://youtu.be/COgkwGGIXYo
All axis working https://youtu.be/z23VY4WnKQA

I use T8 8mm screw length 1000mm picth 2mm lead 12mm trapezoidal screw with brass copper nut for optimize speed.
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/T8-8mm-screw-length-1000mm-picth-2mm-lead-12mm-trapezoidal-screw-with-brass-copper-nut-1pcs/32659162592.html
I am working too at external case : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2308911

The X axis motor mount are damaged by the intensive use, the redesigned replacement is EjeXIzdaV58.stl

The new electronic enclosure for Arduino DUE, Ramps-FD. 6x Tl-Smoothers, OrangePi PC for OctoPrint and more ;) with an internal 120 mm fan https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2452202

title: G230 Replacement hinge
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Replacement part for G230 Stereo Gaming Headset.

The weakest part about the headset is the swivel hinge, which tends to brake sooner or later, like it did to me.

You will need:
-Soldering tools
-4 x M3x10mm screws (Per hinge)
-4 x M3 nut (Per hinge)
-Printed hinge

How to replace bought hinges:

  1. Disassemble the right speaker (Not all screws are the same, so take note)
  2. Unsolder the right speaker (Note the polarity)
  3. Pull the cable through the head peace
    (The cable is most likely glued outside the speaker enclosure, so be careful when tearing it away)
  4. Disassemble the left speaker
  5. Disassemble the hinges and replace them
  6. Put everything back together

I printed the Top_1 and Bottom_1 with HobbyKing ABS plastic with 0,075 layer height(0,2 is also good, but i wanted to see what happens) and 40% infill (20% is sufficient, but I want it forever). The print was orientated like the STL files with support material, but the support material was very hard to remove, so I made the second version, that has no holes for the screw and nut.

After you print yours, you will need to file the two sides, which face each other and the shaft connecting speaker enclosure to the headpiece.

Because I ran out of M3x10mm screws, I used M3x12mm screws for the right headphone.

description.text:
This is a pod I made for my old balsa wood glider RC plane called "Blue Phoenix" from hobbyträ Sweden.

It´s designed for this camera gimbal But other gimbals that uses a servo of same size as base should fit, no guarantee though.
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/fatshark-700tvl-cmos-fpv-camera-ntsc-pal-with-pan-and-tilt.html

The pod replaces the planes battery hatch and holds the fatshark servo gimbal.
Print the two parts and use M3 nuts and countersunk screws to attach the lip on the bottom of the pod, It´s done this way to have a completely flat base for printing.

I´ve also made a universal version with 4 screw-holes so you can attach it to anything that is more or less flat.

If you print any of these and use them, please share some pictures of it.
Enjoy!

title: GEP130X Camera, XT60 and LED-Circle Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The GEP130X is an awesome 130mm sized mini copter frame. Here are a couple parts I designed for it.

-FPV Camera Mount:
To mount my aomway fpv camera (http://goo.gl/kgM3la) to the frame I designed the camera mount. The camera mount is a two piece part that clamps the camera lense in between.
There is a 15° and a 25° uptilt version.

-XT60 Connector Mount:
Because I didn't like the loose XT60 connector I designed a mount for it. It's supposed to work with the Amass XT60 cable that comes with the frame. It's one like this: goo.gl/bHfsSu. The XT60 connector snaps into place very easily. No tools needed.

-LED Circle Mount:
Later I decided to add a little led circle to the back.
I bought this little 7 bit led circle: http://goo.gl/vThnkK.
To easily mount it I added two clamping arms to the XT60 holder.
This makes mountig it super easy.

My quad performs insanely well.
The motor,propeller & battery combo is just amazing.

I used the following parts:
-Geprc GEP130X (frame)
-RotorX RX3040T (propeller)
-4xRS1306 3300kv CCW (motors)
-Racerstar RS20Ax4 20A 4 in 1 V1 (ESC)
-Giant Power Dinogy 800mAh 14.8V 4S 65C (battery)
-F3 V3.1 Flight Control Board (I wanted the F3 V4 but they sent the wrong one)
-Aomway 700TVL HD 1/3'' CMOS FPV Camera 170 Degree Wide Angle (camera)
-Eachine VTX03 (VTX)
-10cm PCI U.FL / IPX to RP-SMA Female (cable for vtx)
-10Pcs Aluminum Alloy M3×6mm green (screws)
-CJMCU 7 Bit WS2812 (LED circle)
& these 3d printed mounts for the camera, XT60 ant the LED circle

All up weight is 249g!

title: Ceiling Grid Clip for Speaker
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Have a ceiling grid in your basement and want to easily attach speakers or other items? This might be the part you need.

I wanted to mount speakers for a home theater system in my basement, but I was having trouble tracking down ceiling grid clips for my speakers. The ones I did find were a little too expensive for what I wanted. I designed these using OpenSCAD so parameters could be adjusted depending on your speaker size and placement. Currently, the "nail" mount will work with just about any keyhole mounting hole.

I have small 4" speakers so you may want to adjust the post_extender parameter if you have something bigger. The weight of my small speakers has no effect on grid stability, but use common sense with what you end up hanging.

I also have an experimental "ball mount" within the script, but it appears that a) the ball isn't the right size yet b) there are some structural issues with the ball attachment. The eventual goal is to be able to position the speaker at various angles.

Print Settings:

I used simple PLA, 10% infill and 2 shells and 0.200 mm resolution (default settings on my Makerbot Replicator+) and didn't have a problem. These parameters don't seem to matter much, but you may want to increase infill to boost strength. Print with clip laying on its body with nail pointing up (yes, it'll print the nail cap just fine).

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/ePwn4AvY4bq

I am currently using 2" wide flat aluminum stock cut up into 3" pieces to hold two strands of Pixabulbs mounted in a Boscoyo pixabulb mounting strip. The angles are calculated for a 180' tree of 24 strands. My mega tree has 12 hooks on the topper for these clips. I use two of these to sandwich the two pixabulb strips together and secure with nuts & bolts. (Note: there is overlap of the strips at the top between these two clips.)

I am currently printing them and testing different materials. This is a work in progress. You could also use the design for a CNC if you have access to one to cut aluminum stock.
